case_name: Seth Gulabchand v. heirs and legal representatives of Seth Govindram Seksaria

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 795 of 1963 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 795 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and decree dated November 24, 1958, of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Special Appeal No. 5 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated November 24, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Indore in Civil Special Appeal No. 5 of 1949.

facts.text: Suit filed by Seth Gulabchand (plaintiff/appellant) against heirs of Seth Govindram Seksaria for specific performance of agreement dated February 28, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: arises out of a suit filed by the appellant, Seth Gulabchand, hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff, against heirs and legal representatives of Seth Govindram Seksaria, on the original side of the High Court of the former Indore State for specific performance of an agreement dated February 28, 1941,

facts.text: Sanghi, J. decreed the suit on June 11, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: entered into between the plaintiff and the deceased Govindram. Sanghi, J., decreed the suit on June 11, 1948.

facts.text: Defendants appealed to Division Bench of Madhya Bharat High Court; plaintiff filed cross-appeal; Division Bench reversed decree and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment and decree, the defendants filed an appeal to a Division Bench of the Madhya Bharat High Court and the plaintiff also preferred a cross appeal. The Division Bench accepted the defendants appeal, reversed the judgment and decree of Sanghi, J., and dismissed the plaintiffs suit as also his cross appeal.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed appeal under S. 25 of Madhya Bharat High Court of Judicature Act, 1949; Full Bench initially held incompetent, Supreme Court remitted for merits; Full Bench dismissed on remand.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the plaintiff filed an appeal under S. 25 of the Madhya Bharat High Court of Judicature Act, 1949, as it stood before it was amended by Madhya Bharat Act No. 3 of 1950. When this appeal came up for hearing before a Full Bench of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, a preliminary objection as to the competency of the appeal was taken on behalf of the defendants-responents. The Full Bench held that the appeal was incompetent, but this Court, on appeal, held that the appeal was competent and remitted the case to the High Court for decision on merits. On remand the Full Bench upheld the decision of the Division Bench and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Deed of partnership entered on July 17, 1935 between Govindram Seksaria, Brijlal Ramjidas, Bilasrai Joharmal and four others for managing/selling agents of Indore Malwa United Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Govindram Seksaria, Brijlal Ramjidas, Bilasrai Joharmal and four other persons entered into a deed of partnership on July 17, 1935 for carrying on the business of acting as Managing Agents and Selling Agents of Indore Malwa United Mills Ltd., a company owning a textile mill in Indore.

facts.text: Serious disputes arose between the partners.

anchor.surface_text: Serious disputes arose between the partners.

facts.text: Board of Directors appointed Committee in November 1940: R.C. Jall (Chairman), Seth Hiralal, plaintiff (Gulabchand) to enquire into allegations against Govindram, Brijlal, Bilasrai.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Directors of the Company appointed a Committee in November 1940 to enquire into certain allegations made against Govindram Seksaria, Brijlal and Bilasrai. The Committee consisted of Mr. R. C. Jall as Chairman, and Seth Hiralal and the plaintiff as members.

facts.text: Partners referred disputes to arbitration of Col. Dina Nath; award on February 8, 1941: Govindram to buy 5 annas shares of Brijlal (2.5) and Bilasrai (2.5) at par, plus debentures.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the partners referred their differences to the arbitration of Col. Dina Nath, the Prime Minister of the former Holkar State. On February 8, 1941, the Arbitrator gave an award, inter alia deciding that Govindram Seksaria should buy up the five- annas shares of Brijlal Ramjidas and Bilasrai Joharmal at par and that the latter should sell their respective shares of annas two and a half each in the rupee at par and also sell the debentures held by them to Govindram Seksaria at par.

facts.text: Brijlal and Bilasrai instituted suit on February 12, 1941 in Bombay High Court contesting award; failed before Bombay HC and Privy Council.

anchor.surface_text: On February 12, 1941, Brijlal and Bilasrai instituted a suit in the Bombay High Court against Govindram and other partners of the Managing Agency contesting the validity of the award made by Col. Dina Nath. They failed before the Bombay High Court and ultimately before the Privy Council.

facts.text: Agreement dated February 28, 1941 between plaintiff and Govindram for 2.5 annas share.

anchor.surface_text: for specific performance of an agreement dated February 28, 1941, entered into between the plaintiff and the deceased Govindram.

facts.text: Govindram died in May 1946.

anchor.surface_text: who had died in the meantime in May 1946.

facts.text: Deed of assignment of 4 annas share of Brijlal/Bilasrai executed November 5, 1947 in favour of defendants (Govindram's legal representatives).

anchor.surface_text: On November 5, 1947, a deed of assignment of the four-annas share of Brijlal and Bilasrai was executed in favour of the defendants as legal representatives of Govindram,

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit on November 6, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On November 6, 1947, the plaintiff instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises.

facts.text: Issue No. 4: Whether agreement was bribe by Govindram to plaintiff for favorable report as Committee member. Division Bench and Full Bench held proved.

anchor.surface_text: Various issues were raised in this suit but it is only necessary to mention issue No. 4, which was as follows Was the agreement to sell the two and a half annas share a bribe offered by the deceased Seth Govindram to the plaintiff to write a report favourable to him, the plaintiff being a member of the Committee of three persons appointed by the Directors of the Malwa Mills, Indore to enquire into and report on the management of the Mills by Seth Govindram? Both the Division Bench and the Full Bench on appeal have held this issue to be proved

facts.text: Govindram sent letter to Jall and plaintiff on February 13, 1941 about award.

anchor.surface_text: After the award was made Govindram addressed a letter to Mr. Jall as a member of the Enquiry Committee on February 13, 1941, intimating to him that the Prime Minister of the Holkar State had given an award on February 8, 1941, in his favour, and forwarding a copy of the award. On the same date Govindram addressed a similar letter to the plaintiff.

facts.text: Day or two after letter, Govindram met plaintiff at house and offered 2.5 annas share from Brijlal/Bilasrai; plaintiff accepted next day; agreement concluded February 28, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: A day or two after the receipt of this letter by the plaintiff Govindram met him at his house and made him an offer of making him a partner of the managing agency firm by assigning two and half annas shares out of the share of Brijlal and Bilasrai which he was to get under the award. The next day the plaintiff accepted the offer and on February 28, 1941, the agreement was concluded between the parties.

facts.text: Plaintiff wrote to Jall on February 27, 1941 urging daily Committee meetings.

anchor.surface_text: A day before the agreement was signed by the parties, Gulabchand, Plaintiff, addressed a letter to Mr. Jall, the Chairman of the Enquiry Committee, on February 27, 1941, for holding the meetings of the Committee daily so as to expedite its report.

facts.text: Govindram offered 1 anna share to Jall on February 8, 1941; Jall rejected as Committee member.

anchor.surface_text: On February 8, 1941, Govindram met Mr. Jall, and offered to sell to him one anna share, which he rejected saying that as he was the member of the Enquiry Committee, it would look as if he was making the offer to please him.

facts.text: Committee final report April 7, 1941 favorable to Govindram; interim report December 16, 1940 less favorable.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee gave its final report on April 7, 1941, which was favourable to Govindram, although the interim report dated December 16, 1940, was not too favourable to him.

facts.text: Plaintiff had no previous experience of mill working or as managing agent.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff had no previous experience of the working of any Mill and had never been a managing agent of any textile mill.

facts.text: Govindram was a rich millionaire.

anchor.surface_text: Govindram was a rich man and a millionaire.

facts.text: In 1942, Govindram suggested reducing share to 1.5 annas; plaintiff did not accept.

anchor.surface_text: In 1942 Govindram suggested to the plaintiff that the share to be sold to him should be reduced to one and a half annas, but the plaintiff did not accept the suggestion.

facts.text: Later in 1942, Govindram told Jall he did not intend to give share to plaintiff, planned to donate entire 4 annas to Holkar State charity.

anchor.surface_text: Later, in 1942, when Mr. Jall questioned Govindram about the intended reduction in the share which was to be sold to the plaintiff, Govindram replied that he did not really intend to give any share to the plaintiff or anyone and that he proposed to give the entire four-annas share to the Holkar State by way of charity.

facts.text: Courts inferred offer was bribe to induce favorable report; plaintiff accepted as such.

anchor.surface_text: From all these facts the Division Bench inferred and concluded that the offer of two and a half annas share by Govindram to the plaintiff, Gulabchand, was a bribe in order to induce him to report in his favour and was accepted as such by Gulabchand. This conclusion was challenged before the Full Bench on various grounds, but the Full Bench upheld the decision.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 24, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Indore in Civil Special Appeal No. 5 of 1949.

issues.text: Was the agreement to sell the two and a half annas share a bribe offered by the deceased Seth Govindram to the plaintiff to write a report favourable to him, the plaintiff being a member of the Committee of three persons appointed by the Directors of the Malwa Mills, Indore to enquire into and report on the management of the Mills by Seth Govindram?

issues.text: Whether, in a civil suit where bribery is alleged, the standard of proof required is beyond reasonable doubt as in a criminal case

anchor.surface_text: They were not required -to prove that fact beyond reasonable doubt as in a criminal case. Mr. C. B. Aggarwala, while admitting that concurrent finding of fact cannot ordinarily be assailed before this Court, contends that in this case there is noevidence in support of the findings arrived at by the Full Bench and that the findings are based on mere surmises. He further says that the Full Bench has misdirected urges that where bribery is alleged in a civil case the same standard of proof should be required as in a criminal matter.

issues.text: Whether Hiralal's evidence was admissible, having not been put to the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: Hiralals evidence was sought to be ruled out on the ground that what he had stated in his evidence had not been put to the plaintiff. HiralaI had deposed that after the award the plaintiff saw him and told him that there was some settlement between him and Govindram. It is not necessary to decide this point because the Full Bench did not base its findings on Hiralals. evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Another argument urged by him is that there was no proof at all that the plaintiff was a party to the intention of Govindram to bribe him. He says that there is presumption that the plaintiff acted honestly and nomaterial has been placed to displace that presumption.

issues.text: Whether, in a civil case where fraud or bribery is to be inferred from circumstances, those circumstances must exclude any other reasonable possibility

anchor.surface_text: where fraud is to be inferred from the circumstances, and is not directly proved, those circumstances must be such as to exclude any other reasonable possibility. In other words, the criterion is similar to that which is applicable to circumstantial evidence in criminal cases.

issues.text: Whether 'immorality' within s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act is confined to sexual immorality

anchor.surface_text: immorality within s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act is confined to sexual immorality, but we are not concerned with the question whether the consideration is immoral or not.

Weston v. Peary MohanDass 1 . And speaking for myself where, whatever be the form of the proceeding, charges of a fraudulent or criminal character are made against a party thereto, it is right to insist that such charges be proved clearly and beyond reasonable doubt, though the nature and extent of such proof must necessarily vary according to the circumstances of each case.

precedents.cited_proposition: Evidence Act applies prudent man standard; no criminal standard for civil fraud cases
precedents.cited_holding: Demonstrations, or a conclusion at all points logical cannot be expected nor can a degree of certainty be demanded of which the matter under investigation is not reasonably capable.

anchor.surface_text: In our I.L.R. 39 Cal. 245 . 16 C.W.N. 265. I.L.R 49 Cal. 132. opinion, Woodroffe, J., was wrong in insisting that such charges must be proved clearly and beyond reasonable doubt.

Mr. Aggarwala, relying on Raja Singh v. Chaichoo Singh 1  further urges that in case of circumstantial evidence the circumstances must be such -so as to exclude any other reasonable possibility and he says that if this principle is applied to this case the finding of bribery must be reversed as the facts are equally companysistent with the plaintiff having acted honestly.

precedents.cited_proposition: where fraud inferred from circumstances in civil case, circumstances must exclude any other reasonable possibility, similar to criminal circumstantial evidence
precedents.cited_holding: Now it is well-settled that where fraud is to be inferred from the circumstances, and is not directly proved, those circumstances must be such as to exclude any other reasonable possibility. In other words, the criterion is similar to that which is applicable to circumstantial evidence in criminal cases.

anchor.surface_text: In s. 3 of the Indian Evidence Act, the words proved, disproved and not proved and defined as follows Proved.--A fact is said to be proved when, after considering the matters before it, the Court either believes it to exist, or considers -its existence so probable that a prudent man ought, under the circumstances of the particular case, to act upon the supposition that it exists.
